Raynaud's phenomenon (RP): paroxysmal vascular acrosyndrome with vasoconstriction, triggered by exposure to cold.

Erythermalgia: paroxysmal vascular acrosyndrome with vasodilatation, triggered by heat, exercise or orthostatism.

Acrocyanosis: permanent vascular acrosyndrome with a pronounced cold, cyanotic appearance of the extremities.

Frostbite: trophic acrosyndrome in the toes, more rarely in the fingers.

Digital ischaemia: ischaemia localised to the fingers or toes.

question.title: What is the primary characteristic of Raynaud's phenomenon?

option_a.title: Cold-induced
option_a.description: Raynaud's phenomenon is triggered by exposure to cold.

option_b.title: Heat-induced
option_b.description: Erythermalgia is triggered by heat, exercise or orthostatism.

option_c.title: Vasodilatation
option_c.description: Acrocyanosis is characterized by a pronounced cold, cyanotic appearance of the extremities.

option_d.title: Trophic acrosyndrome
option_d.description: Frostbite is a trophic acrosyndrome in the toes, more rarely in the fingers.

correct_option.title: Cold-induced
correct_option.description: Raynaud's phenomenon is triggered by exposure to cold.
